channel.title: Satish Iyer's Tech Blog
channel.description: Recent content on Satish Iyer's Tech Blog

item.title: Start Zsh Without any Overheads
item.description:
To start Zsh without overheads.

zsh -d -f ;

-f is local rc and -d is global rcs

item.title: Arch Update Gets Locked
item.description:
If your Arch Package manager gets locked

Sometimes the @arch linux package gets locked so we need to unlock it using `sudo rm /var/lib/pacman/db.lck``

item.title: Github and Bitbucket setup
item.description:
> eval `ssh-agent -s`

$> ssh-keygen -t rsa -C <usename/email>
$> pbcopy id_rsa_bitbucket.pub # Use xsel or xclip in linux
----> go to Bitbucket and add this.
$> ssh-add -D  ---> only if you want to delete previous entries
$> ssh-add id_rsa_bitbucket
$> ssh -T bb
$> vim config ---> to write the config

The config file should look like this:

#Bitbucket (work)
  Host bb
  HostName bitbucket.org
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket

Go to the .git repository and change the url from https:// to ssh://git@github.com:xxx/ Need to remember that the bitbucket also accepts this: git@bitbucket.org:<repo_owner>/.git

item.title: Jrnl - Manage your notes and journal entries from Command line
item.description:
Making alias for @jrnl - j in my zsh. Earlier it was aliased to ‘jobs-l’. Basic Usage jrnl has two modes: composing and viewing. Basically, whenever you don’t supply any arguments that start with a dash or double-dash, you’re in composing mode, meaning you can write your entry on the command line or an editor of your choice.

We intentionally break a convention on command line arguments: all arguments starting with a single dash will filter your journal before viewing it, and can be combined arbitrarily. Arguments with a double dash will control how your journal is displayed or exported and are mutually exclusive (ie. you can only specify one way to display or export your journal at a time).
